title: How many units will Ford produce in North America in 2021?
possible_answers: More than 2.00 million but fewer than 2.25 million
correct_answer: More than 2.00 million but fewer than 2.25 million
preds: 3/11 previous months haven't produced enough to make the total >2m. Never produced enough in a months to go from 1.861-2.25m https://s23.q4cdn.com/799033206/files/doc_news/2021/12/November-2021-Sales-Release-Final.pdf

If wrong, listen to downard trend, aka base rate, more. If correct, calculating the possibilities month by month through 2021 is more precise than the overview base rate, which lacks resolution/precision.

November production at 178,562 for a ytd total of 1,861,334. 140k in December certainly seems doable but, as it's been all year, it's not over 'til it's over. https://s23.q4cdn.com/799033206/files/doc_news/2021/12/November-2021-Sales-Release-Final.pdf

Latest release shows 140k to go in December to hit 2 million, which they've been readily surpassing. https://shareholder.ford.com/investors/events-and-presentations/event-details/2021/Ford-US-November-2021-Sales-Release/default.aspx

I presume production is slower during the holiday season than the months leading up.  This slightly moves down the probability that they hit 2.0M cars.  
If we assume 3 days out of November & and 3 days out of December are at half production, that's a 5% reduction in overall volume.   That's 17k cars, which pulls us to just 2.01M cars.    Last year, the drop in Nov/Dec. was roughly 20%, but I don't have enough data to know if this is anomalous or a seasonal annual production impairment.   I think it's probably much closer to 50/50 than people are giving credit for.

October was 201,353 putting the year at 1,682,796 so far, which is stronger than I'd expected. with only 160k/mo to top 2m it seems very likely now. Needing over 285k/mo to top 2.25m seems very unlikely. https://s23.q4cdn.com/799033206/files/doc_news/2021/11/October-2021-Sales-Release-Final.pdf

The production numbers of 2021 already consider the chips shortage. As for my baseline forecast, linearly adding 3 months to the 1.48 million vehicles produced, result in a 1.97 million number of vehicles for 2021.  consider following scenarios: 
- What needs to happen in order to get below 1.75 million vehicles?
stronger slowdown of chip deliveries than expected - What needs to happen in order to be between 2.00 and 2.25 million vehicles?
this is likely since carmakers expect a slight resurge of chip deliveries - What needs to happen in order to be between 2.25 and 2.50 million vehicles? 
Not so likely since there’s an expected slight increase of chip deliveries. That would be an increase of at least 10%.

Still favoring bin 2 for the overall trend downward over the years and the relative lull during the holiday season, ironically. However, the recent year's trend seems to be going up so bin 3, where the crowd median favors, is also plausible. But then I factor in the rise in COVID cases worldwide and in the USA, as well as the past 10 months MEDIAN and multiply it by 12 months in 2021, I get bin 2. I'm sticking to outside view of general decrease over the years as well as inside view of COVID impacts and the holidays coming up. Minor nudges to crowd rational and recent year's trend.
Revised position based on the numbers provided by @Kahscho

I revised my prior forecast after reviewing Ford's October production number (201K units).  Ford need only produce 159K units/month for Nov. and Dec. to exceed 2M.  Ford was well above this level in 2020. Greater than 2.25M is still well out of reach -- would require 284K units/month in Nov. and Dec.

Sources:
https://s23.q4cdn.com/799033206/files/doc_news/2021/10/September-2021-Sales-Release.pdf (2021data for first three calendar quarters) https://s23.q4cdn.com/799033206/files/doc_financials/2020/q4/Ford-Q4-2020-Sales-Release-Final.pdf (calendar year 2020 data) I was unable to locate production data for pre-COVID years, but several sources indicated that Ford sold 2.4M units in 2019. https://s23.q4cdn.com/799033206/files/doc_financials/2021/q3/Ford-3Q2021-Earnings-Transcript.pdf (Oct. 27, 2021 analyst call) On Oct. 27, 2021 analyst call, Ford indicated that chip shortage was improving, but continues to remain an issue and will likely remain an issue into 2022/2023.   ANALYSIS: To reach 1.75M units, Ford would only need to produce 90K units/month for the rest of the year.  They are well on track to do so.  Barring major catostrophe, Ford will exceed this threshold. To reach 2.0M units, Ford would need to produce 518557 in last calendar quarter.  In Q4 2020, Ford produced 517675 units.  But looking at production numbers from Aug. and Sept. 2021, they appear to be on track to do so.  I would expect lower numbers in Nov. and Dec. 2021 due to the holidays. To reach 2.25M units, Ford would need to produce an average of 256K units/month for the last three months of the year.  They have not reached those numbers in the past two years (even in pre-pandemic Jan. and Feb. 2020).  With the chip shortage, this seems highly unlikely. CONCLUSION: The 2021 production numbers should be pretty close to 2M -- either slightly above or slightly below.
Based on a very dubious simulation

1,682,796 with two months left. To exceed 1.75 million: 33.6k a month
To exceed 2 million: 158.6k a month
To exceed 2.25 million: 283.6k a month October was 201k. Average of last three months was 203k a month. I'm switching to favor 2 to 2.25 million. https://shareholder.ford.com/files/doc_news/2021/11/October-2021-Sales-Release-Final.pdf

Doesn't sound like much info came out of the earnings call other than Ford said chip shortage is easing a bit. Don't know how that will translate to production though, but I'm coming up a little bit on 2 to 2.25, might switch to favor it depending on October numbers once we see those. September numbers for future reference: https://s23.q4cdn.com/799033206/files/doc_news/2021/10/September-2021-Sales-Release.pdf Note to self sales releases will be here usually in the first week of the month: https://shareholder.ford.com/investors/events-and-presentations/default.aspx

Thanks to @Scappleby year to date production at end of September is 1,481,443. Month of August was 226k, month of September was 183k, both higher than June and July numbers (~125k each). Some scenarios below: Averages 125k remainder of year = 1.86 million
Averages 183k remainder of the year = 2.03 million
Averages  226k remainder of the year = 2.16 million Based on that I'm narrowing on 1.75 to 2.25, slightly favoring 1.75 to 2.00 million.

183k in Sept puts it at 1,481,443 for the year so far which means production is normalizing but looking slightly more likely to fall short of the 2M mark https://s23.q4cdn.com/799033206/files/doc_news/2021/10/September-2021-Sales-Release.pdf

September Results (183k) came in better than expected (165k): 
https://s23.q4cdn.com/799033206/files/doc_news/2021/10/September-2021-Sales-Release.pdf
Used other forecasters but slightly more optimistic. Demand up with Covid.
Modest downward shift ahead of new numbers.
Demand will be strong for the Electric vehicles but supply chains on all components will create challenges, especially semi conductors.

The trend has been down over the years. Factoring the drops because of COVID and the bin 3 forecast from Ford itself, I think it's a safe bet for bins 1 and 2 and 3, adjusting lower due to the decreasing trend and possibly optimistic forecast from Ford and perhaps its neglect in seeing another wave since the forecast.

Updated my Monte Carlo Simulation for all production data through 9/1/2021 Total Production Through 9/1:  1.298M
Monthly Average:  ~160k
Monthly Std. Dev: ~45k Simulated Mean:  1.939M produced
Simulated Stdev through Year End:  87k https://shareholder.ford.com/investors/events-and-presentations/event-details/2021/default.aspx

Ford state production figures in June at ~950K units produced so far this year.  They did not release specific figures but based on August and July sales and inventory totals released we estimate that current YTD production is 1.275M units.  Using mean monthly averages we arrive at an expected production total of 1.9M units.  We feel the most likely scenario is 1.75 - 2M.  We feel the second most likely scenario is that the Ford exceeds these values slightly on the high end.  One of the events which exacerbated supply shortage was the February freeze in Texas where numerous large scale semiconductor companies have operations.  As these events move further in the past the supply chain, while still crimped will not be as crimped.  The order book is strong enough for Ford to continue producing.  The 3rd most likely event is a significant miss of numbers as a result of supply chain shortages.  We find any high beats to be unlikely.
Thanks to @Scappleby for pointing out the enormous leap in August output.

2018 Sales were 2.5 mil; 2019 sales were 2.3. 2020 sales were 2.0.
Article says sales rebounded due to pent up demand, but were hindered due to chip shortage.
Then article claims 1.28 mil fewer vehicles could be produced this year by the 6 major automakers.
1.28m / 6 companies = ~200k for ford.
Assume pent up demand increased sales from 2020's 2.0m to 2.3, and then chip shortage decreases by 200k = 2.1m
This answer lends itself to 2m<x<2.25m. If Ford has a higher percentage share of the big 6 automakers, then we might see 300k decrease, placing us in 1.75m<x<2m. (or if pent up demand did not return sales to the 2018 level.

If production normalizes to ~185k/month it's looking close to 2m total but more likely to fall short.

Transitioning into another forecast but not quite to maintain continuity with my previous forecast. I could go wrong by not putting enough weight on the in-between space between pre-pandemic baselines and where we currently are, as well as not weighing enough Ford's self projection of 2.17 or so? I'll update to my new forecast as soon as applicable. Perhaps August 27.
Tweaking to increase 2.25 to 2.5, possible all the supply chain issues could be overcome and they could have a bigger than expected half.

Starting off here will update as i reasearch more
As noted by others and mentioned in Ford`s press release
https://s23.q4cdn.com/799033206/files/doc_news/2021/06/June-2021-Sales-Release.pdf
H1 2021 production is 946397. They expect sequential growth of 30% and that means close to 2.177mn vehicles for the year subject to the evolving semi conductor issue
In the Ford call transcript they have partly blamed Renesas (while Renesas have in their own call mentioned normalcy resuming in Aug) There was this by Elon musk a few days ago.
https://electrek.co/2021/08/12/elon-musk-puts-renesas-bosch-on-blast-for-tesla-extreme-supply-chain-limitations/ I am being a bit more pessimistic given that what the management implies is an H2 number slightly higher than normal( ie higher than avg SALES volumes in H2 over the last 3 years)
Underlying demand remains strong and my concern remains only on the supply chain issues  Ford Call transcript - https://s23.q4cdn.com/799033206/files/doc_financials/2021/q2/Ford-2Q2021-Earnings-Transcript.pdf

"GM expected chip supplies to return to normal in the second half of the year." (Most other estimates seem to say it will last longer)
"The Alliance for Auto Innovation, the trade group that represents automakers, said the shortage could hurt auto production for another six months and result in 1.28 million fewer vehicles being made in the U.S. this year."
 https://www.freep.com/story/money/cars/2021/06/15/car-chip-shortage-2021/7688773002/  "Around 13.4 million motor vehicles were produced in North America in 2020." https://www.statista.com/statistics/204208/north-america-vehicle-production-since-1990/  (avg was ~17.5m/yr in the 5 years previous) Ford has ~14% market share in North America, so averaged ~2.45m/year in the previous 5 years. The chip shortage could reduce that numbers by ~180k. 2021 Q1 production was 587k So... 2.45 less 180k is 2.27. As @Ryan-Beck noted (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1319897), combined Q1/Q2 was 861k, so Q2 was 274, which tracks with the 50% reduction that was forecast in April.  Of note "Ford Still Has Over 60,000 Incomplete Vehicles Waiting for Chips" (July 28) https://www.thedrive.com/news/41738/ford-still-has-over-60000-incomplete-vehicles-waiting-for-chips . So we could have a late game surge if chips become available. If they normalize in the next couple months (~550-600k/q) That pushes it just over 2m. 2.25 seems a stretch, but still possible. Lets see what Q3 brings...

I can rationalize each bin quite well with data and Ford's own forecast, but I am seeing a lower result more likely. However, I can see bin 3 or 4 realizing if things can return to normal. The central tendency seems to be around 2M plus or minus so it makes sense to have half my percetage points below this and half above this. I really think there is a shot for the last two bins because that's where the area is between COVID low and baseline prior to COVID. However, if the trend continues downward, the first bin is open to steal the show.

The Q2 earnings press release [1] shows 861,000 vehicles in the first half of 2021 in North America. They also project 30% volume growth for the second half. That would put the total at 1,980,000. It sounds like part of this growth is based on the expectation of a recovery in semiconductor availability. It's possible that doesn't happen. Also the 30% is probably globally and could be an underestimate say they can hit their target so I'm leaving plenty of uncertainty. [1] https://shareholder.ford.com/investors/financials-and-filings/default.aspx

Based on info @ForecastingNovice found => Ford's central estimate = 2.17m
Ford are assuming 30% uplift on H1 production as chip shortage eases in H2 2021
I'm putting 23% into bucket 2 under scenario where this easing is optimistic
Most weight into bucket 3, i.e. Ford broadly correct
Very small weighting into bucket 4 -> would require production to return to pre-pandemic levels almost immediately
Ford produced 946397 in the first half and projected a 30% increase in the 2nd half in their Q2 report.  That would put them at 2.17M, but with the Delta spike, they may be too optimistic here.
